00034 // This header file defines internal utilities needed for implementing
00035 // death tests.  They are subject to change without notice.

00037 #ifndef GTEST_INCLUDE_GTEST_INTERNAL_GTEST_DEATH_TEST_INTERNAL_H_
00038 #define GTEST_INCLUDE_GTEST_INTERNAL_GTEST_DEATH_TEST_INTERNAL_H_
00039 
00040 #include <gtest/internal/gtest-internal.h>
00041 
00042 namespace testing {
00043 namespace internal {
00044 
00045 GTEST_DECLARE_string_(internal_run_death_test);
00046 
00047 // Names of the flags (needed for parsing Google Test flags).
00048 const char kDeathTestStyleFlag[] = "death_test_style";
00049 const char kInternalRunDeathTestFlag[] = "internal_run_death_test";
00050 
00051 #ifdef GTEST_HAS_DEATH_TEST
00052 
00053 // DeathTest is a class that hides much of the complexity of the
00054 // GTEST_DEATH_TEST_ macro.  It is abstract; its static Create method
00055 // returns a concrete class that depends on the prevailing death test
00056 // style, as defined by the --gtest_death_test_style and/or
00057 // --gtest_internal_run_death_test flags.
00058 
00059 // In describing the results of death tests, these terms are used with
00060 // the corresponding definitions:
00061 //
00062 // exit status:  The integer exit information in the format specified
00063 //               by wait(2)
00064 // exit code:    The integer code passed to exit(3), _exit(2), or
00065 //               returned from main()
00066 class DeathTest {
00067  public:
00068   // Create returns false if there was an error determining the
00069   // appropriate action to take for the current death test; for example,
00070   // if the gtest_death_test_style flag is set to an invalid value.
00071   // The LastMessage method will return a more detailed message in that
00072   // case.  Otherwise, the DeathTest pointer pointed to by the "test"
00073   // argument is set.  If the death test should be skipped, the pointer
00074   // is set to NULL; otherwise, it is set to the address of a new concrete
00075   // DeathTest object that controls the execution of the current test.
00076   static bool Create(const char* statement, const RE* regex,
00077                      const char* file, int line, DeathTest** test);
00078   DeathTest();
00079   virtual ~DeathTest() { }
00080 
00081   // A helper class that aborts a death test when it's deleted.
00082   class ReturnSentinel {
00083    public:
00084     explicit ReturnSentinel(DeathTest* test) : test_(test) { }
00085     ~ReturnSentinel() { test_->Abort(TEST_ENCOUNTERED_RETURN_STATEMENT); }
00086    private:
00087     DeathTest* const test_;
00088     GTEST_DISALLOW_COPY_AND_ASSIGN_(ReturnSentinel);
00089   } GTEST_ATTRIBUTE_UNUSED_;
00090 
00091   // An enumeration of possible roles that may be taken when a death
00092   // test is encountered.  EXECUTE means that the death test logic should
00093   // be executed immediately.  OVERSEE means that the program should prepare
00094   // the appropriate environment for a child process to execute the death
00095   // test, then wait for it to complete.
00096   enum TestRole { OVERSEE_TEST, EXECUTE_TEST };
00097 
00098   // An enumeration of the two reasons that a test might be aborted.
00099   enum AbortReason { TEST_ENCOUNTERED_RETURN_STATEMENT, TEST_DID_NOT_DIE };
00100 
00101   // Assumes one of the above roles.
00102   virtual TestRole AssumeRole() = 0;
00103 
00104   // Waits for the death test to finish and returns its status.
00105   virtual int Wait() = 0;
00106 
00107   // Returns true if the death test passed; that is, the test process
00108   // exited during the test, its exit status matches a user-supplied
00109   // predicate, and its stderr output matches a user-supplied regular
00110   // expression.
00111   // The user-supplied predicate may be a macro expression rather
00112   // than a function pointer or functor, or else Wait and Passed could
00113   // be combined.
00114   virtual bool Passed(bool exit_status_ok) = 0;
00115 
00116   // Signals that the death test did not die as expected.
00117   virtual void Abort(AbortReason reason) = 0;
00118 
00119   // Returns a human-readable outcome message regarding the outcome of
00120   // the last death test.
00121   static const char* LastMessage();
00122 
00123  private:
00124   GTEST_DISALLOW_COPY_AND_ASSIGN_(DeathTest);
00125 };
00126 
00127 // Factory interface for death tests.  May be mocked out for testing.
00128 class DeathTestFactory {
00129  public:
00130   virtual ~DeathTestFactory() { }
00131   virtual bool Create(const char* statement, const RE* regex,
00132                       const char* file, int line, DeathTest** test) = 0;
00133 };
00134 
00135 // A concrete DeathTestFactory implementation for normal use.
00136 class DefaultDeathTestFactory : public DeathTestFactory {
00137  public:
00138   virtual bool Create(const char* statement, const RE* regex,
00139                       const char* file, int line, DeathTest** test);
00140 };
00141 
00142 // Returns true if exit_status describes a process that was terminated
00143 // by a signal, or exited normally with a nonzero exit code.
00144 bool ExitedUnsuccessfully(int exit_status);
00145 
00146 // This macro is for implementing ASSERT_DEATH*, EXPECT_DEATH*,
00147 // ASSERT_EXIT*, and EXPECT_EXIT*.
00148 #define GTEST_DEATH_TEST_(statement, predicate, regex, fail) \
00149   GTEST_AMBIGUOUS_ELSE_BLOCKER_ \
00150   if (true) { \
00151     const ::testing::internal::RE& gtest_regex = (regex); \
00152     ::testing::internal::DeathTest* gtest_dt; \
00153     if (!::testing::internal::DeathTest::Create(#statement, &gtest_regex, \
00154         __FILE__, __LINE__, &gtest_dt)) { \
00155       goto GTEST_CONCAT_TOKEN_(gtest_label_, __LINE__); \
00156     } \
00157     if (gtest_dt != NULL) { \
00158       ::testing::internal::scoped_ptr< ::testing::internal::DeathTest> \
00159           gtest_dt_ptr(gtest_dt); \
00160       switch (gtest_dt->AssumeRole()) { \
00161         case ::testing::internal::DeathTest::OVERSEE_TEST: \
00162           if (!gtest_dt->Passed(predicate(gtest_dt->Wait()))) { \
00163             goto GTEST_CONCAT_TOKEN_(gtest_label_, __LINE__); \
00164           } \
00165           break; \
00166         case ::testing::internal::DeathTest::EXECUTE_TEST: { \
00167           ::testing::internal::DeathTest::ReturnSentinel \
00168               gtest_sentinel(gtest_dt); \
00169           { statement; } \
00170           gtest_dt->Abort(::testing::internal::DeathTest::TEST_DID_NOT_DIE); \
00171           break; \
00172         } \
00173       } \
00174     } \
00175   } else \
00176     GTEST_CONCAT_TOKEN_(gtest_label_, __LINE__): \
00177       fail(::testing::internal::DeathTest::LastMessage())
00178 // The symbol "fail" here expands to something into which a message
00179 // can be streamed.
00180 
00181 // A struct representing the parsed contents of the
00182 // --gtest_internal_run_death_test flag, as it existed when
00183 // RUN_ALL_TESTS was called.
00184 struct InternalRunDeathTestFlag {
00185   String file;
00186   int line;
00187   int index;
00188   int status_fd;
00189 };
00190 
00191 // Returns a newly created InternalRunDeathTestFlag object with fields
00192 // initialized from the GTEST_FLAG(internal_run_death_test) flag if
00193 // the flag is specified; otherwise returns NULL.
00194 InternalRunDeathTestFlag* ParseInternalRunDeathTestFlag();
00195 
00196 #endif  // GTEST_HAS_DEATH_TEST
00197 
00198 }  // namespace internal
00199 }  // namespace testing
00200 
00201 #endif  // GTEST_INCLUDE_GTEST_INTERNAL_GTEST_DEATH_TEST_INTERNAL_H_
